content:
The "Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Act of 2000" establishes the Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Program, defining terms like Pacific Ocean drainage area and Secretary of the Interior. The Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Program aims to reduce fish mortality caused by water withdrawals for irrigation while allowing continued water use. It also aims to prevent fish from entering water supply systems. The Program involves developing projects to mitigate impacts on fisheries from water diversions in the Pacific Ocean drainage area. The Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Program focuses on reducing fish mortality from water diversions in the Pacific Ocean drainage area. Eligible projects include fish screens, passage devices, and related features. Priority is given to projects costing less than $5,000,000. Non-Federal participation in the Fisheries Restoration and Irrigation Mitigation Program is voluntary. The Secretary will not hold non-Federal entities financially responsible unless they apply to participate. Projects on U.S. owned land will not require reimbursement. Evaluation and prioritization of projects are outlined in Section 5. Evaluation and prioritization of projects for development under the Program will be based on benefits to native fish species, size and type of water diversion, availability of funding sources, cost effectiveness, and additional opportunities for biological or water delivery system benefits. Eligibility requirements are outlined in Section 6. Eligibility requirements for projects under the Program include meeting Secretary and State requirements, approval from all relevant entities, and consultation with various agencies for project eligibility determination. Non-Federal participants in projects under the Program must provide 35 percent of the cost for projects on non-government-owned land or facilities. They are also responsible for providing necessary land, easements, rights-of-way, and other resources for the project. The value of these contributions can be credited towards the non-Federal share of project costs. The non-Federal participants in projects under the Program are responsible for all costs associated with operating, maintaining, repairing, rehabilitating, and replacing the project on non-government-owned land or facilities. The Federal Government is responsible for these costs for projects on Federal land or at a Federal facility. SEC. 8. LIMITATION ON ELIGIBILITY FOR FUNDING. Projects funded under this Act cannot receive additional federal funds for the same purpose. 

SEC. 9. REPORT. After three fiscal years, the Secretary must report to Congress on completed projects, those in progress, and recommended Program changes.

SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $25,000,000 authorized annually for fiscal years 2001-2005.
